body: Added _Worst Case Scenario_ section to issue description.

issue.title: Introduce default test class name pattern

milestone.title: 5.0 M3
milestone.description: Themes: JUnit 4 interoperability, additional discovery selectors.

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: ✅ The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

Since classpath scanning may potentially eagerly load classes unnecessarily, the JUnit 5 Team has decided to introduce default patterns for test class names. Doing so will help to reduce the number of candidate classes loaded when scanning the classpath for test classes.
## Related Issues
- #474 
## Deliverables
- [x] Introduce the regular expression `^.*Tests?$` as the default class name pattern for test classes.
  - [x] in `ConsoleLauncher`
  - [x] in the JUnit Platform Gradle Plugin
  - [x] in the `JUnitPlatform` `Runner`, but only if the runner is used as a _suite_
- [x] Document AND vs OR semantics for class name filters (see https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/474#issuecomment-246189318)

body:
**Team Decisions**:
- Apply filtering based on the configured test class name regular expression _before_ loading a class during classpath scanning.
- Continue to apply filtering as a `PostDiscoveryFilter` in order to exclude classes selected by means other than classpath scanning (e.g., selection by class, method, UID, etc.).

issue.title: Introduce support for filtering packages

milestone.title: 5.0 M3
milestone.description: Themes: JUnit 4 interoperability, additional discovery selectors.

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: ✅ The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Status Quo

It is currently possible to _select_ a package -- for example, for classpath scanning. However, it is not possible to _filter_ packages.

See use case described in #534 for additional input.
## Related Issues
- #301
- #312 
- #314
- #437 
- #474
- #534 
## Deliverables
- [x] Introduce _include_ and _exclude_ filter support for packages in a new `PackageFilter` class (similar to `ClassFilter`).
- [x] Introduce _include_ and _exclude_ filter support for packages in the Gradle JUnit Platform plugin.
- [x] Introduce _include_ and _exclude_ filter support for packages in the `JUnitPlatform` runner (e.g., `@IncludePackages` and `@ExcludePackages`).

issue.title: Introduce support for excluding classes via filters

milestone.title: 5.0 M4
milestone.description: Themes: test templates, repeated tests, and parameterized tests.

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: ✅ The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Status Quo

It is currently possible to _filter_ a class for _inclusion_ but **not** for _exclusion_.

## Related Issues
- #301
- #312 
- #313 
- #474

## Deliverables
- [x] Introduce _exclude_ support in `ClassNameFilter` (e.g., `excludeClassNamePatterns()`)
- [x] Introduce _exclude_ filter support for classes in the `ConsoleLauncher` (e.g., `-N` and `--exclude-classname`).
- [x] Introduce _exclude_ filter support for classes in the Gradle JUnit Platform plugin (e.g., `excludeClassNamePattern()` and `excludeClassNamePatterns()`).
- [x] Introduce _exclude_ filter support for classes in the `JUnitPlatform` runner (e.g., `@ExcludeClassNamePatterns`).

body:
@junit-team/junit-lambda, I am reopening this issue in order to discuss the following.

I wonder if we really want to compose the filters with AND semantics in `ClasspathScanningSupport`.

For example, if a user specifies `^.+TestCase$` and `^.+Tests$` as class name patterns, no tests would be executed since a class cannot end with "TestCase" _and_ "Tests" simultaneously.

One alternative would be to compose them with OR semantics.

Another possibility would be to throw an exception if there is more than one `ClassNameFilter` registered in the discovery request.

If we opt for the latter, we would then need to document that only a single pattern is supported and that multiple patterns must be combined into a single regular expression.

Actually, we'll have to document the semantics (AND vs OR) in either case. I'll add a note to #490 to address that.
